question: Read the following statement about Vedanta Philosophy: (i) Vedantaexplores consciousness as fundamental to reality itself. (ii) It posits that the ultimate reality (Brahman) is pure consciousness (chit) and that individual consciousness (atman) is essentially identical to Brahman. (iii) This non-dualistic view suggests that understanding one's true nature leads to realizing the unity of consciousness with the universal.
options: Only (i) and (iii) are correct.
(i), (ii) and (iii) are correct.
only (iii) is correct.
Only (i) and (ii) are correct.

question: Ethical Governance and Rulershipin Manusmriti: "Having fully controlled his own senses, he should seek to subdue his foes; a king who has subdued his own senses is fit to subdue his foes."
options: This emphasizes the importance of self-control and unethical behavior for a ruler. A king who masters his own senses and desires is better equipped to govern justly and effectively.
This emphasizes the importance of non-self-control and ethical behavior for a ruler. A king who masters his own senses and desires is better equipped to govern justly and effectively.
This emphasizes the importance of self-control and ethical behavior for a ruler. A king who masters his own senses and desires is better equipped to govern justly and effectively.
This emphasizes the importance of self-control and ethical behavior for a ruler. A king who masters others senses and desires is better equipped to govern unjustly.
answer: This emphasizes the importance of self-control and ethical behavior for a ruler. A king who masters his own senses and desires is better equipped to govern justly and effectively.

question: Philosophical Inquiry and Understanding as per Manusmriti 4.178: "He who desires to reach the highest goal must study the Veda with great care; the knowledge of the Veda is said to be the supreme wealth of a Brahmana."
